content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student conducts a solubility experiment with potassium nitrate, <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, in water by identifying the temperature at which various masses of <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> will completely dissolve.

(a) At room temperature, <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> is a liquid and <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is a solid. The student incorrectly claims that this is because potassium and nitrate ions experience stronger dispersion forces than <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> molecules. In terms of the types of attractive forces, explain why the student is incorrect.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student conducts a solubility experiment with potassium nitrate, <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, in water by identifying the temperature at which various masses of <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> will completely dissolve.

(a) At room temperature, <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> is a liquid and <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is a solid. The student incorrectly claims that this is because potassium and nitrate ions experience stronger dispersion forces than <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> molecules. In terms of the types of attractive forces, explain why the student is incorrect.
(b) In one of the trials, the student reads the initial temperature of the water using the Celsius thermometer above. Record this temperature to the appropriate number of significant figures.

(c) At the temperature indicated on the thermometer, the student adds the solid <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> to the sample of water and begins to stir the mixture. Explain the effect of stirring on the maximum amount of solid that can dissolve in the water.

The graph above summarizes the data collected by the student.
(d) Another student places <math alttext="38.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>38.1</mn></math> grams of <math alttext="K N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> into <math alttext="100.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of water at the temperature measured in part (b), stirs the mixture, and observes that the solid does not dissolve completely. The student plans to heat the mixture and states that the solid will completely dissolve before the mixture reaches <math alttext="30 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn><mo>Â°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Do you agree with the claim? Justify your answer with information from the graph.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
